section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with song, and introduce vocabulary (shape, square).
Begin Story Time by asking, What is something in the city that looks like a shape?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, pausing to focus on shapes.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square, rectangle, triangle—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.
Explain that a shape remains the same shape even when its size or position changes.
Think symbolically.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment, such as hills, rivers, roads, lakes, and familiar buildings.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to find squares in pictures.
Help children recognize that the position of a square does not change its shape.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where we live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Do you see any squares in that book?
Where can you find a square in the kitchen?
Count the number of sides on a square.
Draw something in the classroom that is square-shaped.
Can you use these materials to make a square?
Squares have four sides. What letter do you hear at the beginning of four? Trace it!
What shapes do you see in these blocks?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder classify and organize and introduce vocabulary (group, rectangle).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to City Shapes.
Read closely to classify and organize and review shapes.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points.
Explain that a shape remains the same shape even when its size or position changes.
Combine shapes to create a picture or design.
Think symbolically.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Use different materials for exploration and for sensory experience.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment, such as hills, rivers, roads, lakes, and buildings.
Identify flags of the United States and of home state.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to group shapes by whether or not they are rectangles.
Discuss that squares are a type of rectangle.
Challenge children to group cards using other criteria.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where we live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find any rectangles in this book?
When you play in the store, what do you see that is shaped like a rectangle?
Make a rectangle on the Geoboard.
Draw something you see in the classroom that is in the shape of a rectangle.
Use any materials to make a rectangle.
Draw a rectangle around the letter R.
Use blocks to make a building in the shape of a rectangle.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. City Shapes by Diana Murray, illustrated by Bryan Collier. Text copyright © 2016 by Diana Murray. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by Bryan Collier. Cover copyright © 2016 by Hachette Book Group, Inc. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to discuss three-dimensional shapes, play a shape game, and introduce vocabulary (triangle, circle).
Begin Story Time by revisiting City Shapes and asking the guiding question, Where do the girl and the pigeon find shapes in the city?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review geometry.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Begin to recognize common three-dimensional shapes, describing them as balls, boxes, cans, and cones.
Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.
Explain that a shape remains the same shape even when its size or position changes.
Combine shapes to create a picture or design.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment, such as hills, rivers, roads, lakes, and familiar buildings.
Think symbolically.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Understand and use varied types of words.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Identify shapes on Activity Cards, occasionally making a mistake.
Challenge children to correct your mistakes and explain why.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where we live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Find something in the book that is in the shape of a circle or a triangle.
Is there a tool that has a circle on it? Is there a tool that has a triangle on it?
Which Pattern Blocks are triangles?
Write about your favorite thing that is shaped like a circle.
Use any materials to make a square.
Circles are curved. Does the letter C have straight lines or curved lines?
Can you group the blocks by shape?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. City Shapes by Diana Murray, illustrated by Bryan Collier. Text copyright © 2016 by Diana Murray. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by Bryan Collier. Cover copyright © 2016 by Hachette Book Group, Inc. tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Our Neighborhood

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about where we live, engage children with a game, and introduce vocabulary (post office, library).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Our Neighborhood and City Shapes.
Read closely to connect to this week’s concept question, What is it like where we live?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square, rectangle, triangle—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.
Combine shapes to create a picture or design.
Think symbolically.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment, such as hills, rivers, roads, lakes, and familiar buildings.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to find shapes in the classroom.
Guide children to repeat the name of the shape.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where we live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How is the place in this story like your community? How is it different?
Play post office. What shape is an envelope?
What shape are the counters? How many are there?
What is your favorite place to go in your community? What do you do there?
Can you draw your favorite shape?
Choose a place in your community. What letter do you hear at the beginning of that place? Can you draw it?
Use blocks to build a home.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. City Shapes by Diana Murray, illustrated by Bryan Collier. Text copyright © 2016 by Diana Murray. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by Bryan Collier. Cover copyright © 2016 by Hachette Book Group, Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Little, Brown Books for Young Readers, a division of Hachette Book Group, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to connect to fine arts and introduce new vocabulary (skyscraper).
Start Story Time by revisiting the big book and asking, How can we use shapes to draw the things we see in our neighborhood?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and a focus on shapes.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square, rectangle, triangle—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.
Combine shapes to create a picture or design.
Think symbolically.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment, such as hills, rivers, roads, lakes, and familiar buildings.
Use different art materials for exploration and sensory experience.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Executive Function

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: Write a story about finding your favorite shape in your neighborhood.
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where we live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Where does this character live? How is it the same as where you live? How is it different?
Pretend that you are a skyscraper. What shape are your windows? What shape is your roof? How tall are you?
Group Pattern Blocks by shape.
If you could build your own skyscraper, what would it be like?
Make a painting of your own skyscraper.
What letter do you hear at the beginning of skyscraper?
Use blocks to build the tallest skyscraper you can.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. City Shapes by Diana Murray, illustrated by Bryan Collier. Text copyright © 2016 by Diana Murray. Illustrations copyright © 2016 by Bryan Collier. Cover copyright © 2016 by Hachette Book Group, Inc. tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Name common shapes.
Slide, flip, and turn shapes to demonstrate that the shapes remain the same.
Think symbolically.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment.
Name common shapes.
Slide, flip, and turn shapes to demonstrate that the shapes remain the same.
Create shapes.
Think symbolically.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Use art materials and activities for sensory experience and exploration.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment.
Identify flags of the United States and Texas.
Name common shapes.
Slide, flip, and turn shapes to demonstrate that the shapes remain the same.
Create shapes.
Think symbolically.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment.
Name common shapes.
Create shapes.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Think symbolically.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment.
Name common shapes.
Create shapes.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Think symbolically.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment.
Use a variety of art materials and activities for sensory experience and exploration.
